RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
This Executive Summary is included in the RMP submit filed with the EPA.
RMP Update

This RMP is an update to the September 2003 RMP, and replaces the 9/03 edition in its entirety.

At this point (October 2008) the facility had been taken out of service indefinitely.  This RMP update generally addresses the station as last operated in May 2008.

No changes have been made to the content of the Off Site Consequence Analysis (Section 5 and Appendix B), so these stand as certified in the September 2003 RMP submitted to the EPA.  The five-year revision to the RMP which would have been submitted to the EPA (due in September 2008) if the station remained in operation, would have included the results of re-examination of the Off Site Consequence Analysis.
CalARP RMP Background

The purpose of the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide guidelines for facilities in California to conduct business in an environmentally safe manner.  The legal authority for the CalARP Program is the California Health and Safety Code, Division 20, Chapter 6.95, Article 2 (commencing with Section 25531).  The California Office of Emergency Services has issued implementation regulations under the California Code of Regulations (CCR) Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  The Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E) Small-Scale Natural Gas Liquefaction Facility (?LNG Facility?) is subject to RMP requirements because the maximum intended inventory of liquefied natural gas (LNG) exceeds the 10,000-pound Federal threshold for methane (this threshold quantity is specified in Table 2 of 19 CCR 2770.5).  This threshold quantity is applicable because natural gas is composed of 96 percent methane.  
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
PG&E is dedicated to protecting employees, the community, and the environment from chemical incidents through safe operation of the facility.  PG&E is committed to providing a safe

place of business for the employees and surrounding community by aiming to create an injury and illness free work environment and a loss free environment for the benefit of themselves, their coworkers, their customers, and the general public.  This RMP document summarizes the programs and procedures in place at the LNG Facility to prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of flammable or explosive chemicals.  The RMP provisions are intended to minimize the probability and/or consequences of accidental releases of highly hazardous chemicals from the facility and include such measures as a system hazard review, operation and maintenance procedures, training, compliance auditing, implementation of a management system, and providing routine updates.
This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the covered process.  PG&E?s policy is to implement industry best practice controls to prevent foreseeable releases.  In the event of an accidental release or other problem, the facility operators and contractors are trained to activate one of the emergency shutdown devices and evacuate the area if/as appropriate.  The ESD system also includes automatic equipment to detect problems and shut down the plant.
Facility
The LNG Facility is located at 2001 Front Street, Sacramento, California.  The facility produces LNG for fueling vehicles and for truck trailers used as portable gas pipeline supply.  The portions of the system subject to CalARP regulations are the LNG liquefaction system, the LNG storage tank, associated piping and equipment, and the operations for transferring LNG from the storage tank to tanker trucks. 
The primary LNG Facility activities are the production, storage, and transfer of LNG to transport trucks.  LNG production and storage is currently accomplished by a PG&E operator with the station automatic co

ntrol system, and will eventually become completely automatic.  LNG transfer from the storage tank to tanker trucks is conducted by PG&E operators.
Chemical Inventories
As LNG is produced at the LNG Facility, it is collected in a storage tank.  The amount stored in the storage tank exceeds the Federal RMP applicability threshold of 10,000 lbs.  The PG&E LNG Facility is subject to Program 3 requirements, as described in Section 7.0 below, because the facility storage quantity triggers the threshold for flammables under Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management regulations (Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations [CFR], Part 1910.119, and 8 CCR 5189) and the facility is not eligible for Program 1.  
Chemical Hazards
Toxicologically, methane is classified as a simple asphyxiant.  The routes of exposure are inhalation and dermal contact.  Methane is inactive biologically and essentially nontoxic.  Therefore, the major properties are the exclusion of an adequate supply of oxygen to the lungs; effects are dizziness, unconsciousness, and eventual collapse.  Skin contact with the LNG or cold piping presents a hazard of cold burn, and results in freezing or frostbite.
The main hazards associated with LNG are fire and explosion.  The flash point of methane is ?306 degrees Fahrenheit (closed cup), the lower flammability limit is 5 percent, and the upper flammability limit is 15 percent.
Hazard Assessment
As part of the PG&E CalARP RMP, the worst-case release scenario (WCS) and alternative-case release scenario (ACS) were identified in accordance with 19 CCR 2745.4.  
The WCS for the facility is assumed to be a catastrophic failure of the LNG storage tank, resulting in the release of the entire contents of the tank to the atmosphere.  The entire quantity is assumed to be released over a period of 10 minutes.  The release rate to the atmosphere is the quantity contained in the tank divided by the duration of the release. Because the SFD will be the responder in the event of an emergency incident involving an LNG fire detect, PG&E conducted a responder orientation exercise with the SFD on March 21, 2008, to familiarize SFD personnel with the facility and the hazards associated with LNG.
Five-Year Accident History
There have been no CalARP RMP reportable releases at the LNG Facility in the past 5 years that resulted in either of the following:
?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
?    Known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
Emergency Response Program
PG&E has implemented an emergency response program (ERP) that complies with the requirements of the CalARP RMP as described in 19 CCR 2765.2.  This program contains a variety of information and procedures which describe how emergencies are handled.
Included in the ERP is the emergency shutdown system (ESD) at the plant.  In the event of an accidental release, the facility operators and contractors are trained to activate the ESD by pushing one of the ESD buttons and to evacuate the area if appropriate.  ESD events which occur because of fire or gas detection signal the fire department approved fire panel to call an answering service for the facility, which in turn contacts PG&E employees.  In the event of a fire detection, the answering service also contacts the Sacramento Fire Department.  Manual ESD buttons do not signal the fire panel; since these will be activated only by personnel already on site, personnel will take the appropriate contact action and no answering service involvement is needed.
Planned Changes to Improve Safety
PG&E is in the process of resolving all of the action items identified in the October 2007 Process Hazard Analyses for each RMP-covered process.  A summary of the status of PHA action items for the facili

ty is presented in Tables 4.2a and 4.2b in Section 4 of this RMP.
In the future, to ensure that the appropriate changes occur as necessary to maintain and improve safety, ongoing Process Hazard Reviews, Process Hazard Analyses, Training, Compliance Audits, inspection and maintenance, Contractor programs, Hot Work Permit issuance, and Incident Investigations will be conducted as required by the RMP.  Program 3 changes will be managed under the Management of Change system.  Updates to the RMP will be completed as necessary in response to these activities.
